Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 10:29PM - edited Apr 19, 2008 10:31PM by sam408 Kathy, It sounds like you should definitely seek a second opinion. If your husband has previous good experience with a PS, you should go talk to him. You will spend a lot of time with the doctor you choose and you really need to feel comfortable with them and their staff. The first time I saw my PS I went in convinced I wanted a bi-lateral and she spent a lot of time explaining all the pros and cons of the surgery to me. She also gave me the name of another PS to see because he was the only one in town who does free flaps. She does pedicled trams and doesn't advise bi-lateral peds due to the muscle loss. She would do it for me if I insisted, but she spent lots of time explaining everything to me. In the end I opted for a unilateral mast with the ped tram performed by her. I'm 2 1/2 weeks out from surgery and don't regret my decision. I will eventually have a lift on the other side and she feels like I'll have good results. Yes, there's still a little worry about reccurance, but I'll cross that bridge if I get to it. I don't know how fast other doctors are, but my PS took 6 hours to do the recon. It may have taken longer because she was working with radiated skin, I'm not sure. So far everything looks good and I don't feel like scars are going to be an issue. We haven't really discussed follow-up stuff like scars or lipo but we did spend a lot of time talking about what size I wanted my recon to be and how to get a good match to the other side. I think your PS is very wrong in saying this is not cosmetic surgery. I feel like that's exactly what it is. The mastectomy is what removes the cancer and saves your life, the recon is what makes you feel whole again and any PS who doesn't understand that probably shouldn't be dealing with bc patients. Sorry for going on so long. I just hate to hear that you feel uncomfortable and rushed. Remember that waiting a month or two to make a decision you're comfortable with will most likely not make a difference in your outcome. Your dx sounds a lot like mine. . .high grade DCIS. What I learned after rushing through surgeries last year was that the cancer had more than likely been in my breast for a long time before being detected and although it was aggressive in nature, it wasn't going to change that much in just a month or two. Unfortunately fear causes us to rush through a lot of the decision process. All I'm saying is to take your time to feel comfortable with your decision. Good luck. Hugs.

I think it's pretty normal. I knew I needed to get off the narcotics but then nothing else cuts the pain like they do and it just sucks to hurt all the time. So sometimes it just got the best of me and I let myself go to that "why me, why can't I have my life back" place (not a real good place to visit). Anyway, it does ease up although I think we're all going to have blue days thanks to this lousy disease but hopefully they'll get farther and farther apart. Hope you feel like going to your grandson's graduation. . .I don't know about you but it definitely makes me feel better to get out of the house. It's interesting to read how differently the PS's are handling your recon. Of course that's what I've found with all the procedures for bc. . .every doctor has their own way of handling it. I've read stories where some women get their other breast augmented at the same time as their mast & recon, but my PS wants to wait a few months until she feels the new one has stopped swelling and has settled into place. It makes sense that it will give her the chance to do a better match, but it sure sucks being lopsided. Now that I'm dealing with this wound, she won't do anything else until it is healed. I'm just hoping it doesn't take months to heal like so many I've read about (it's already been 6 weeks). I hope things continue to go well for both of you. Tina - I may check out those camisoles. I was just trying to spend as little as possible on stuff I won't use after this is all over, but if insurance will pay for it that would be nice. Do you think it would be really hot during the summer? Your story about Target was funny. . .boy do we learn our lessons the hard way! Good thing the attendant was so helpful. Kathy, if you get the shirt big enough or stretchy enough it doesn't involve raising your arms much above your shoulders. But I think you're wise to wait until after the drains are removed. You will be able to move your arms without pain alot more when they're gone. And then putting a shirt over your head can be a reward for putting up with drains for 4 freaking weeks! Take care

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 03:20PM - edited Apr 17, 2008 03:23PM by sam408 Kathy, I had my mast w/tram recon on 4/2 so I'm 2 weeks out from surgery and can tell you that I'm feeling pretty good. The first week was pretty rough and I was in the hospital 4 days of it. Be prepared to feel pretty much like you've been hit by a truck. I saw the PS after one week and she removed the drains. That definitely went a long way in making me feel better. I think just not looking at that gunk makes you feel better. This past week I've just been feeling better every day. I am now only taking pain meds at night to sleep and using tylenol during the day. I'm very close to standing up straight also. I saw the PS today and she said everything looks good. I'm still very swollen and she says that will take at least a month to go down. I don't have to go back to her for 2 more weeks now. It sounds like you've got things in order at home. I didn't use a walker so I'm not sure you'll really need that, plus I was limited in using the arm on my surgical side (not sure I could've even managed a walker). The one thing you might want to consider is your sleeping arrangements. I have an adjustable bed so it hasn't been an issue, but a lot of women either use a recliner or rent a hospital bed. You definitely need to be in a bent position for a while (I still cannot lie flat). You may also want to consider moving things you use a lot down to counter height as it's difficult to reach up when you first get home. I also only had my right side done and I can now reach pretty well with my left arm. Just remember to rest a lot and let hubby take care of you. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 04:50AM sam408 wrote: Hi everyone. I've finally had a chance to read through the posts and I'm glad to hear that everyone has been doing good with their surgeries so far. Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 09:06PM sam408 wrote: Hey Tina, Glad to hear things are going well for you and the second fill was a little better than the first. BTW, I wasn't especially brave or anything to do tram flap surgery. . .flap surgery was the only option I had thanks to radiation. I didn't want to do lat flap, so tram was all I had left (no free flap or DIEP surgeons available in my area). I probably would've opted for a bilateral w/expanders if I'd had the choice. Wish I could wear the camisoles since a bra is still so uncomfortable, but I have to wear an enhancer on my other side to even things out and I don't think the little shelf in a cami would hold it (I may try it out though). Know what you mean about not spending a lot on stuff during this temporary period, but wearing the same thing over and over gets old too. I've purchased several bras trying to find a comfortable one -- a zip front sports bra from Penney's, a couple of front hook leisure bras from Penney's (have to be ordered) and a front hook sports bra from Wal-Mart. The one from Wal-Mart is the one I like the best and it was only $7, definitely a lot cheaper than the ones from Penney's! I've been working on ROM but it sure is tough to do when it hurts. Wonder if I should ask my PS about doing some PT just to get things going. Kathy -- I think I started putting things over my head about week 4. It's mostly tank tops and loose t-shirt because I don't think I could get anything fitted over my head even now. Try some things that are stretchy or a little loose fitting. I just put it over my head first and then get my surgery arm in before the other arm. This might not work for you since you have both arms impaired. With the change in weather, I needed something to wear besides the zip front hoodies and long sleeved shirts I had when I first had surgery. Plus t-shirts with a design on the front help to camoflauge my lopsideness. Good luck, hope you're able to get into some different things.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 10:36PM - edited May 29, 2008 10:37PM by sam408 Kathy - When I weaned off them I just started making the time between doses longer and longer until I got to where I was only taking one very 6-8 hours and then I just went to only taking one at night to help me sleep (I think I got to that point around 4-5 weeks). I never started taking any other meds on a routine basis. I just take Motrin during the day when I feel the need for it, sometimes once a day and sometimes not at all. When I have trouble sleeping I take a Tylenol PM and it works like a charm. I have kept a supply of pain meds to use if I need them. I usually end up taking one on the day I see my PS and she does a lot of poking around and debriding my wound. I'm amazed you couldn't see the drain hole the next day. Now I wonder if they use different size tubes. Even though they closed quickly, both of mine left a scar. Hope you enjoyed getting out of the house and hope it made you feel better. Take care and big hugs

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 04:44PM - edited May 23, 2008 04:47PM by sam408 I had a lumpectomy and rads last year and developed a seroma a couple of months after completing rads. Since I also had a lot of contracture from the rads, my surgeon felt it was what caused the seroma too. She aspirated it a few times but it would fill back within a month and was quite painful. In the end my surgeon suggested that I proceed with a mastectomy to get rid of the tissue that wasn't healing properly. She felt, and I agreed, that I didn't have breast conserving surgery to end up with a painful, deformed breast. So I had unilateral mast with pedicled tram flap recon last month and so far things are going well. I'm 7 weeks out from surgery and the only problem I'm having is a small wound that my PS says is going to take a while to heal (thanks to the radiated skin) but she is confident it will heal. Good luck with your treatments. I personally couldn't deal with the constant pain and needle aspirations I was going through.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 11:26AM sam408 wrote: Kira -- I know the first reaction we all have is to get out (I had my lumpectomy 6 days after dx). I can't say now whether or not I'd have done things differently, but I do wish I'd slowed down a little and researched things more. I had no idea radiation would limit treatment options if I needed a mastectomy later (which I did). Does you doctor feel your surgery can't wait until after the wedding? I worry that you may not physically feel well in 4 weeks. Some people breeze through these surgeries and some do not, unfortunately we never know how it's going to turn out until afterward. As someone said earlier, you can use the time prior to the wedding to research, get second opinions, have other tests, etc.  I think there are lots of women who have waited longer than 4 weeks for their surgery and it hasn't affected their outcome. The waiting is horrendous, I know, but it may be in your best interest so you can be in good shape for the wedding. Good luck with the wedding. My daughter is getting married next March and I'm hoping to get my next surgery done this fall so I can be healed and ready. I'm currently healing from mast/tram on 4/2 and will be doing a lift on the other side in 3-4 months. Don't know if this has helped you any, good luck with your decision. It's a tough one and everyone makes it for their own reasons. Stay in touch and let us know how you're doing. Hugs

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 03:54PM sam408 wrote: soapsnug -- I have seen a GS through all my procedures (2 biopsies, lumpectomy w/SNB and unilateral mastectomy). She does beautiful work and had it not been for radiation completely screwing up my breast tissue, the scars would be very minimal. She was the one who suggested mastectomy with recon when my breast became so disfigured after rads. She was very sensitive to the fact that I ended up with a pretty ugly boob and told me it didn't have to be that way. She did the mast and referred me to an excellent PS who did the immediate tram flap recon. Although I've still got some healing to do and maybe some more revision by the PS, I think I'm on my way to decent looking breasts (the PS just did a lift on the "good" breast). Anyway, I love my GS and am glad to have such a good relationship with her just in case I need any other surgeries. I agree with the others that you need to do what you feel comfortable with and if seeing a BS would put your mind at ease, then by all means do it. Good luck with your decision. Hugs to you

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 11:28AM - edited May 16, 2008 10:01PM by sam408 I agree that you shouldn't take anything prior to surgery without clearing it with your drs. But do take the stool softeners as long as you're on the pain meds. I didn't heed this advice and paid for it last week when the constipation became pretty much unbearable. The fact that I'm recovering from a tram and couldn't push made matters even worse. Anyway, here's a tip I got off the internet in the middle of the night when I was trying to get through this. Put your feet on a small stool in front of the toilet so that your knees are higher than your waist. Then lean forward and this puts your body in a squatting position which lines everything up and was the way our bodies were designed to eliminate. It worked! Stay on top of this bowel movement thing. You will be miserable if you don't. I definitely won't let myself get in that shape again.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 05:51PM sam408 wrote: Robyn - My husband was also reluctant to talk about it in the beginning. I did wait until I had my dx and tx plan before I talked to very many people about it, but I had to push him to tell his Mom and sisters. Since I was the first in our family to have bc, it was very difficult to tell my Mom, 3 sisters and 2 daughters, so I needed him to help me pass the news on to others who we felt needed to know. I think that helped him feel that he was helping me. . .does that make sense. Now that I've been through a year of treatment, he talks to everyone about it. An interesting thing about neighbors. . .the ones that live across the street from us have been there about 20 years but we're still just on a friendly-neighbor basis with them (you know, talk out in the yard when you see each other). It's still the original guy that bought the house, but a new wife of about 5 years. Anyway, last summer during one of our conversations my bc came up. Come to find out, his wife had bc in 2003. . .her tx was mast w/expanders & implants. It was all done during the winter when we rarely see each other and by the time summer rolled around, she never mentioned it. Now she's talked to me about it several times and we are able to offer support to each other. Had I not been open with them about my bc, odds are I may never have known about hers and now we're closer than we were plus the husbands seem to have a closer bond. So you never know what opening up to someone may bring.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 02:44PM sam408 wrote: You should ask your PS how he handles post surgery care. I had a unilateral tram flap and my PS didn't want me wearing anything that would constrict the breast because she feels it constricts the blood flow to the flap. As you read the experiences of different women, you'll find that most doctors have a certain way of doing things and it's not always the same as what another one does. But if your PS has a good track record, then I would follow whatever routine he sets up. I didn't wear any type of bra/camisole until about 4 weeks out and then began wearing front hook sports bras only. Wal-Mart sells a nice one that only costs $7. In the last couple of weeks I have graduated to regular bras, but they're still a little uncomfortable (I'm 12 weeks out). During the time I wasn't wearing a bra, I found that layering my tops camoflauged it nicely. I just wore t-shirts/tank tops with an unbuttoned blouse over them. As far as drains, you will have at least one ab drain if you have DIEP; some people have two. I had one breast drain and one ab drain. I pinned them to a lanyard that hung around my neck. That kept them in front of me when I was moving around and make it less likely to get them hung on something. The hospital provided me with a couple of the lanyards so I had an extra that I could get wet in the shower. When I made my first trip out of the house, I wore a loose fitting warm-up set and tucked them in the waistband of the pants. Luckily that was my first follow-up with the PS and she removed the drains that day (8 days post surgery). Again, I would ask your PS what post-surgery care he uses and go from there. It may save you from buying unnecessary items. Good luck with your surgery.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 10:09AM sam408 wrote: I went through this same scenario with my 83 year old mother in law in January. She insisted there was no need to check it out because she wasn't going to do any treatment. I convinced her to at least get it checked out and removed if it was cancer. She got the needle biopsy and the results were B9. The needle biopsy is a very simple procedure and produces very little pain. Remember, approximately 80% of these things are benign so the odds are in your favor. I've actually had two benign biopsies since my diagnosis. It is definitely in your best interest to get it checked out and proceed from there. A lot of cancers are not invasive and can be removed completely in surgery. Good luck with your decision. Hugs

Posts.Content: sam408 wrote: The fun just never stops with this thing. . . I was diagnosed with DCIS in February, had a lumpectomy with clean margins and finished radiation at the end of May. I had no node involvement so did not need chemo. Over the last few weeks I developed a large collection of fluid at the surgical site and went to my surgeon to have it looked at because it was causing me a lot of pain. During her exam she found a lump in my other breast. She felt it may be fluid too but wanted to check it out further to be sure. In the end I went for an ultrasound yesterday to have both lumps looked at. They confirmed the one on the surgical breast was fluid and were able to aspirate it all off. Unfortunately the one on my other breast was not fluid and they did a core biopsy on the spot. I should have results tomorrow, but am not playing the waiting game as well as I did the last time. Last time I clung to those 80/20 odds and convinced myself that everything would be all right. After falling into the 20% side, I'm just not as optimistic this time. This thing just sucks and I'm angry that I didn't even get 6 months out of treatment before I'm staring it in the face again. I think I'm ready to kiss these girls goodbye and get a new pair. The bc breast looks like crap from the lumpectomy scar (tumor was very close to the chest wall, so scar is across the top of my breast) and the radiation caused the tissue to contract badly, so it is just very unattractive to look at.  Now with this new business going on in the other breast, I just can't take living with the constant fear. Also, the tamoxifen makes my joints ache and I feel like a 90 year old woman most of the time. Can anyone tell me if you have the bilateral do you still take tamoxifen? I would love to get off that stuff. Sorry for the long post, I just had to get it off my chest. The support of everyone on this board definitely helps make this thing a little easier to do. Sheila Sheila . . .Never regret something that made you smile. Dx 2/16/2007, DCIS, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 11:24AM sam408 wrote: clueless - Since you have a lump that can be felt, I don't think you will have a wire localization. When I had my first surgery last year, I had only microcalcifications that showed up on the mammo, so the wire had to be inserted to guide the surgeon to where they were. I just had another excisional biopsy in March to remove a lump in my other breast and it did not require the wire since it could be felt. The incision was made along the edge of my aerola and it is barely noticable now. . .surgery was on March 19. I wore a sports bra 24/7 for 2 weeks following both of those surgeries and I do believe it makes a huge difference to keep that breast immobilized. Just make sure you don't get anything that has to be pulled over your head because you won't be able to get it on. My suggestion for surgery day - button/zip up shirt, pull on pants, slip on shoes and sports bra to wear home. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 12:55AM sam408 wrote: MaryLynn -  This is such a personal decision and it's one you have to feel good about no matter what others have done. My dx was .7 cm DCIS and I originally opted for lumpectomy followed by radiation because it's the least invasive surgery and I wanted to save my breast. Unfortunately I did not react well to rads and my tissue never healed. This is not a common occurance. In order to correct this situation I needed to remove the bad tissue. I seriously considered having a bi-lateral but in the end I couldn't emotionally deal with losing my good breast. So last month I had a mastectomy on my right breast with immediate ped tram flap recon. So far I'm happy with the results and will eventually have my remaining breast lifted to match the new one. Good luck with your decision. Continue to ask questions on this site, the women here are so supportive.
